accused.name: Jennon fille feu le Petit Poirson

witnesses.name: Elizabeth femme a Colas Grand Demenge

testimony.quarrel_subject: Property settlement - accused refused to place goods 'au plus vivant'

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: fell ill after returning from feste a Migneville

testimony.quarrel_subject: Dispute over watering animals - asked accused to hold hers back

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: immediately after - calf rushed into cow's side

testimony.quarrel_subject: Accused's husband didn't want to live in Leintrey
Not being invited when witness gave birth

witnesses.name: Chrestienne veuve de Guillaumin Jean Vatrix

timeline.subject: Jennon Poirson
timeline.details: Preliminary investigations began with witness testimonies

timeline.subject: Jennon Poirson
timeline.details: Accused interrogated, declared age about 46, explained life history and service positions

timeline.subject: Jennon Poirson
timeline.details: Confrontations with witnesses held same day as interrogation; mild argument over icy/snowy conditions during cow incident

timeline.subject: Jennon Poirson
timeline.details: Change de Nancy orders that she be renvoyée (released)

torture.restrictions: Request denied - accused was released instead

accomplices_named.name: Jennon Bailly
accomplices_named.context: Accused of dancing in fields with Jennon Poirson; wife of Nicolas Bailly; left village when suspicion arose

prior_accusations.context: Dancing in fields with Jennon Bailly witnessed by curé Messire Jean Donnerey approximately 5-9 years before trial

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon Bailly
notable_quotes.context: When she returned claiming to be pursued by horseman

notable_quotes.speaker: Claudon Grand Demenge (dying husband)
notable_quotes.french: si tu en mange, tu en prinse
notable_quotes.english: if you eat it, you will be harmed/poisoned

notable_quotes.speaker: Claudon Grand Demenge (on deathbed)
notable_quotes.context: Telling his brother about his illness
notable_quotes.french: frappé a mort, mais qu'une femme en estoit cause
notable_quotes.english: struck to death, but that a woman was the cause

notable_quotes.speaker: Curé Messire Jean Donnerey
notable_quotes.french: Qui fit soupconner au commun qu'elles estoient sorcieres Mesmement ledit feu Curé dit qu'il n'avoit jamais voulu croire qu'il fut des sorcieres mais qu'a ceste heure la il le croyoit
notable_quotes.english: Which made the common people suspect they were witches. Especially the late Curé said he had never wanted to believe there were witches but at that time he believed it

notable_quotes.speaker: Elizabeth (witness 1) explaining husband's suspicions
notable_quotes.context: Why she didn't believe dying husband suspected his wife
notable_quotes.french: tellement que ladite deposante impute telles parolles a la contrainte de la malladie dudit deffunct parce qu'il estoit comme troublé
notable_quotes.english: such that the witness attributes such words to the constraint of the illness of the deceased because he was as if troubled/confused

relationships.evidence_text: Her late husband who died after some 18 months of marriage
daughter of Le Petit Poirson and his wife Catherine Nicolas Gerard
Elizabeth femme a Colas Grand Demenge
Jennon Bailly wife to Nicolas Bailly
Five years before had given birth to son called Bastien
Chrestienne veuve de Guillaumin Jean Vatrix
after year in service there with Nicolas du Vaulx, married late husband
Colas Grand Demenge was brother of her late husband
Elizabeth was wife of her husband's brother
Both natives of Leintrey, lived as neighbors

economic_context.details: Major dispute with brother-in-law over property settlement. Husband wanted Jennon to place their goods 'au plus vivant' (to the survivor) which she refused. This refusal was mentioned multiple times and linked to his subsequent illness and death. Also tension over accused's desire to return to native Leintrey versus husband's preference to stay in Gondrexon.

harms_catalog.harm_description: Illness and death after dispute over property settlement
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Refusal to place goods 'au plus vivant' and daily quarrels between spouses
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: fell ill after returning from feste a Migneville following repeated request about property

harms_catalog.harm_description: Unable to stand after being hit by calf, had to be killed in spring; butcher could see no natural reason
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Dispute over watering animals - witness asked accused to hold her animals back
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: immediately - calf rushed into cow's side during the watering incident

harms_catalog.harm_description: Temporary loss of milk after giving birth to son Bastien
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Not being invited when witness gave birth - suggested neighbor was angry

material_culture.context: Jennon brought sugar from Ogieviller for her dying husband; he refused to eat it and warned Elizabeth not to eat it
Colas Claudon testified he saw Jennon Bailly take communion twice but appear not to swallow the host, leading to suspicion of being Huguenot or witch
Dispute over placing goods 'au plus vivant' (property settlement to survivor)

spatial_references.context: Accused's native village and residence at time of trial; also where she returned to live as widow
Village where accused lived with husband; where most witnesses resided and incidents occurred
One of the places where accused worked in service
Place where accused worked in service
Place where accused worked in service
Place where accused worked in service
Place where accused worked in service
Place where accused worked in service
Where Jennon obtained sugar for her dying husband
Location of 'feste' (festival) that Claudon attended before falling ill
Location where accused was allegedly seen dancing with Jennon Bailly; witnessed by curé's boy and reported by curé Messire Jean Donnerey
Where accused accompanied Jennon Bailly partway, and where Bailly claimed to see horseman
Where incident with cow occurred during time of Brandons (Carnival)

weather_events: icy/snowy conditions during Brandons (Carnival season, late winter) when cow incident occurred - dispute between witnesses about whether icy or just snowy
religious_calendar_references: Brandons (Carnival/Shrovetide) - time when cow incident occurred
communion practices - suspicion around not swallowing host

change_de_nancy.modification_details: Change de Nancy rejected the procureur fiscal's request for torture and ordered the accused to be released (renvoyée)

hearsay_chains.content: Dancing episode and suspicions about brother's death - explicitly noted as hearsay and unclear timeframe
Saw dancing in fields with Jennon Bailly
That milk loss might be because neighbor angry at not being invited
Curé's boy saw two women dancing in fields; one identified as Jennon Bailly
Dancing episode - curé was primary source for this key reputation element

emotional_state_notes: Offered normal explanations for points put to her during interrogation
Mild argument during confrontation over weather conditions (icy vs snowy)

reproaches_to_witnesses.objection: Denied some apparently harmless points in stories, such as giving husband sugar
During confrontation, disputed weather conditions - said it was so icy animals could hardly stand, while witness said there was only snow

third_parties.name: Messire Jean Donnerey
third_parties.relationship_to_accused: curé (priest) of Gondrexon when she lived there
third_parties.context: Late curé who witnessed or whose boy witnessed the dancing incident; primary source for reputation of witchcraft; reportedly said he never believed in witches until he saw the dancing

third_parties.name: Jennon Bailly
third_parties.context: Wife of Nicolas Bailly, suspected witch who allegedly danced in fields with accused; left village when suspicion arose; visited accused at Gondrexon returning from Leintrey

third_parties.name: Nicolas Bailly
third_parties.relationship_to_accused: husband of alleged accomplice Jennon Bailly
third_parties.context: Husband of Jennon Bailly who was suspected of witchcraft

third_parties.name: Nicolas du Vaulx
third_parties.context: Master in Gondrexon where accused served for a year before marrying

third_parties.name: Bastien
third_parties.context: Son born to witness who experienced milk loss attributed to accused

third_parties.name: la Jobarde
third_parties.context: Witness 7 thought dancing had been with la Jobarde rather than Jennon Bailly - variant account

third_parties.name: curé's boy
third_parties.context: Son of curé Messire Jean Donnerey who reportedly first saw the two women dancing in fields

third_parties.name: butcher
third_parties.context: Examined cow that couldn't stand and found no natural reason for inability to stand

third_parties.name: father-in-law (of accused)
third_parties.context: Identified the other woman dancing as Jennon (accused) whom Jennon Bailly had visited at Leintrey

extraction_metadata.notes: Complete trial record with clear outcome. Notable for: (1) Release ordered by Change de Nancy despite torture request, (2) Central role of dancing incident witnessed/reported by curé as foundation of reputation, (3) Property dispute with dying husband as main accusation, (4) Two favorable character witnesses (8 and 9) who saw no evil in her, (5) Accused's age calculation inconsistent (claimed 46 but service years don't add up - likely younger), (6) Religious element of suspected host desecration by accomplice Jennon Bailly. Trial shows importance of curé's testimony and property disputes within families.
